case:judges.case:judge: Moffitt P, Reynolds and Glass JJA

p.text: (with whose judgment Reynolds JA and Glass JA concurred).

The appellant seeks to place his case on the fresh evidence ground on the Supreme Court Act s 75A(8) asserting that there are “special grounds” which warrant the court receiving the further evidence. Seeking to rely on English authority upon a statutory provision the equivalent of s 75A(8), he argued that decision should not be governed by the essentials to be met before a new trial is granted which are stated in Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan (1955) 93 CLR 435; 29 ALJR 36 and that the test of “special grounds” provided by the subsection, permits decision pursuant to the exercise of discretion on a wider and more flexible basis. As will be seen, the disposal of this appeal does not call for discussion of what may comprise “special grounds” in other cases and in particular whether considerations, and, if so, which, beyond the matters referred to in Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan, 1above, might lead to the order of a new trial.

It is in point to make some, but limited observations upon the lengthy submissions made by the appellant on this matter, but to do so without finally deciding the limits to the operation of s 75A(8). Prior to and apart from the enactment of s 75A it always had been the law that although the grounds on which a new trial would be granted have been settled by practice, they had never become “completely stereotyped”. As was pointed out in 1954 by the High Court in a case where there was fresh evidence, the court being then constituted as it was in 2Cowan in 1955, such grounds “have always possessed some flexibility and have been governed by the overriding purpose of reconciling the demands of justice with the policy in the public interest of bringing suits to a final end”: McCann v Parsons (1954) 93 CLR 418 at 431; [1955] ALR 14 . There is much to support the view that in making provision for evidence to be admitted before the Court of Appeal s 75A(8) was framed in terms which would avoid confining to some particular inflexible practice what ought to be a wide discretion. 3Cowan is no more than a statement of what common sense in the law says as to how in practice, in the exercise of a discretion to set aside a judgment and order a new trial, the interests of justice to an individual, who has already had his case tried but claims to have discovered some fresh evidence, should be reconciled with the public interest in relation to the finality of litigation. In so far as s 75A(8) in terms can operate to facilitate the taking of a step which may lead to the order of a new trial on the basis of fresh evidence, it is clear that the considerations of justice inherent in the requirement that there be “special grounds” will be of the same quality as the consideration of justice inherent in the exercise of the discretion to order a new trial. It may be that considerations of justice in admitting the evidence may differ, having regard to how the evidence is to be used, if admitted, so that the overall view of what is just may be found to differ according to whether the admission of the evidence can be accommodated by the Court of Appeal itself deciding the case as on a rehearing or whether it can only be accommodated by ordering that the whole case be tried again. What the demands of justice are in either situation may vary from case to case and may be stated differently at different times by different judges, but the ultimate question in the end will be the same; namely to do what is just in the light of all relevant circumstances which will require consideration to be had of the extent to which the policy of the law relating to finality will be interfered with by the course required to be taken.

While the provision made by s 75A(2)(a) may lead to the inference that s 75A(8) applies to that part of the appeal which includes a claim for a new trial, the terms of subss (5), (6), (7), (8) and (9) are those appropriate to the Court of Appeal itself making a determination of the issues in the case. Assuming, without deciding, that subs (8) when providing “the Court shall not receive further evidence except on special grounds” extends to receiving such evidence in aid of a ground of appeal seeking a new trial on the basis of fresh evidence, the court will still have to decide whether to exercise its discretion to order a new trial. It would seem that the exercise of a discretion to admit the evidence on special grounds in aid of the Court of Appeal making its own decisions pursuant to subs (5) by way of rehearing may involve different considerations to those which involve the court receiving fresh evidence, if that is what it does, in aid of ordering a new trial. Where in rehearing the case, the Court of Appeal makes its own decision, drawing inferences and making findings of fact as provided by subs (6) (Warren v Coombes (1979) 142 CLR 531; 23 ALR 405), it may be far less disruptive of the finality of litigation to receive fresh evidence in relation to part of the case, than to “receive” fresh evidence so the whole case is retried, with the possible consequence, as often occurs, that the factual issues are different and the evidence is called afresh and is different. In the present case I do not find any circumstances (eg as was the case in McCann v Parsons, 4above), that warrant the application for a new trial being determined by a consideration of matters other than those referred to in Cowan. 5
